Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A crane is holding a heavy beam in position, and you must immediately help guide it into place before it can be secured.
Story: I was on my lunch break at the construction site, sitting on a pile of lumber, when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, a guy I’d met at a friend’s party last month. “Hey, you know any good places to eat around here?” he texted. I knew he was new in town, and I remembered how lost I’d felt when I first moved here. I wanted to help him out, maybe even suggest a place we could grab a bite together sometime. But just as I started typing a reply, the foreman shouted my name. The crane was swinging a massive steel beam into place, and I was needed right away to help guide it. My gloves were already on, sweat prickling my forehead. If I didn’t get over there, the whole crew would be waiting on me, and the beam could become unstable. I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen, torn between being the helpful acquaintance Mark expected and the reliable laborer my team depended on. My heart pounded as I wrestled with what to do next.
